description:
Deinococcus radiomollis is a species of extremophilic bacterium known for its remarkable tolerance to ionizing radiation and other environmental stresses. It belongs to the genus Deinococcus, a group of bacteria renowned for their exceptional ability to withstand high levels of radiation and other harsh conditions.

Deinococcus radiomollis is a Gram-positive, non-spore-forming, and non-motile coccus (spherical) shaped bacterium. It is characterized by its distinctive pink or reddish-orange pigmentation, which is attributed to the presence of carotenoid pigments in its cell membrane.

What sets Deinococcus radiomollis apart is its exceptional resistance to ionizing radiation, including gamma and X-rays. This species can survive exposure to extremely high doses of radiation that would be lethal to most other organisms. This remarkable trait is believed to be the result of a highly efficient DNA repair mechanism and the production of antioxidant compounds that protect the cell's genetic material and other vital cellular components from radiation-induced damage.

In addition to its radiation resistance, Deinococcus radiomollis is also known to be tolerant to other environmental stressors, such as desiccation, oxidative stress, and extreme temperatures. This versatility allows the bacterium to thrive in a wide range of habitats, including soil, rock surfaces, and even the harsh conditions found in certain radioactive environments.

The study of Deinococcus radiomollis and other radiation-resistant Deinococcus species has contributed to our understanding of the mechanisms underlying extreme stress tolerance in microorganisms and has potential applications in fields such as bioremediation, radiation protection, and space exploration.
